title: Make Nested Macro Invocations in std consistent with the rest of the language.
body:
It appears that at least the `include_*` macros have behavior that is not available to user-created macros: the ability to expand their arguments before parsing.

For example the expression `include_str!(concat!("a","b"))` would work as expected, while user-implemented macros would not have the ability to do so.

To increase consistency with the rest of the language I see the following options in a kind of spectrum:

- Always allow macro composition:
  - This would be a breaking change, as macros would no longer be able to parse  other macro invocations, but it would make them work more intuitively, similar to how nested functions work.
- Give user-created macros the choice to expand their arguments
  - This would give macro developers the choice on how to parse their arguments. While it would not be a breaking change, this could lead to confusion, as some macros would allow nesting while others would not.
- Not allow macro composition at all
  - This would be a breaking change, as crates already depend on this kind of syntax, but would be the easiest option for the language developers to bring consistency.

In any case, I believe not doing anything about this would leave a weird exception in the std library that would bring confusion to newcomers.
